questions.text: Which of the following amino acids can be classified both as polar and uncharged ?

A 30-year-old male presents with lethargy, confusion, and vomiting. Laboratory investigations reveal hyperammonemia, respiratory alkalosis, and elevated orotic acid levels. A deficiency in which of the following enzymes is most likely responsible for his symptoms?

choices.text: Homogentisate oxidase; dark urine upon standing

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the pediatrician for developmental delay and eczema. The parents mention a musty body odor. The child's diet is protein-rich. Laboratory testing reveals elevated phenylalanine levels. Which of the following enzymes is most likely deficient in this child, and what would be a distinguishing clinical feature if untreated?

choices.text: Deficiency of niacin due to impaired tryptophan metabolism
Dietary deficiency of niacin and tryptophan
Impaired absorption of cobalamin leading to megaloblastic anemia
Deficiency of riboflavin affecting energy metabolism

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with photosensitive dermatitis, diarrhea, and episodic ataxia. His family history is unremarkable, and he has no dietary restrictions. Laboratory findings reveal aminoaciduria, specifically increased excretion of neutral amino acids. Which of the following best explains his condition?

choices.text: Glutathione conjugates bilirubin to make it water-soluble
Glutathione reduces hydrogen peroxide to water, preventing oxidative stress
Glutathione facilitates the synthesis of ATP during oxidative phosphorylation
Glutathione activates enzymes involved in hemoglobin production

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with fatigue and jaundice after consuming fava beans. Laboratory tests reveal hemoglobinuria, anemia, and the presence of Heinz bodies on a peripheral blood smear. Which of the following best explains the role of glutathione in preventing this condition?

choices.text: Acts as a cofactor for nitric oxide synthase
Serves as a substrate for nitric oxide production

questions.text: Which of the following is the main role of arginine in nitric oxide synthesis?

choices.text: Vitamin B6, vitamin B12, and folic acid supplementation

questions.text: A 35-year-old male is evaluated for recurrent deep vein thrombosis. Laboratory tests reveal elevated plasma homocysteine levels. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for his condition?

choices.text: A domain is a region of a protein that can fold into a stable, independent structure and perform a specific function
A domain refers to the sequence of amino acids that determines the protein's tertiary structure
A domain is the total number of subunits in a protein's quaternary structure
A domain is a section of the protein that only interacts with other proteins through peptide bonds

questions.text: Which of the following statements best describes a protein domain?

choices.text: Mutations in the COL4A3, COL4A4, or COL4A5 genes
Deficiency of the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase
Deficiency of the enzyme glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase

questions.text: A 14-year-old male presents with progressive hearing loss, hematuria, and a family history of similar symptoms in male relatives. Urinalysis shows microscopic hematuria, and a kidney biopsy reveals thickening and splitting of the glomerular basement membrane. Which of the following is the most likely genetic defect responsible for this condition?

choices.text: The position of the hydroxyl group on the C-2 carbon
The position of the hydroxyl group on the C-4 carbon
The position of the carbonyl group on the C-1 carbon
The position of the hydroxyl group on the C-3 carbon

questions.text: Glucose and mannose are epimers. What is the main difference between these two monosaccharides?
Which of the following glycosaminoglycans (GAGs) does not contain an acidic sugar?

choices.text: GLUT transporters use sodium gradients to transport glucose, while SGLT transporters do not.
GLUT transporters are dependent on active transport, while SGLT transporters use facilitated diffusion.
SGLT transporters use sodium gradients to co-transport glucose, while GLUT transporters facilitate glucose transport without the need for sodium.
SGLT transporters are found primarily in the liver, while GLUT transporters are found primarily in muscle cells.

questions.text: Which of the following is the main difference between GLUT and SGLT transporters?

choices.text: They increase insulin secretion from the pancreas.
They block the reabsorption of glucose from the renal tubules, leading to glucose excretion in urine.
They increase glucose uptake by muscle and adipose tissue.
They reduce hepatic glucose production by inhibiting gluconeogenesis.

questions.text: Which of the following is the primary mechanism of action of SGLT-2 inhibitors in the treatment of type 2 diabetes?

choices.text: It inhibits the enzyme hexokinase, preventing the phosphorylation of glucose.
It inhibits phosphofructokinase-1 (PFK-1), reducing the conversion of fructose-6-phosphate to fructose-1,6-bisphosphate.
It inhibits enolase, preventing the conversion of 2-phosphoglycerate to phosphoenolpyruvate (PEP).
It inhibits pyruvate kinase, preventing the conversion of phosphoenolpyruvate to pyruvate.

questions.text: How does sodium fluoride inhibit glycolysis?
Which of the following enzymes is most commonly deficient in patients with congenital lactic acidosis?

choices.text: Succinate dehydrogenase is a mitochondrial enzyme that catalyzes the conversion of succinate to fumarate, and it requires iron as a cofactor. The enzyme is inhibited by malonate, a competitive inhibitor that mimics succinate.
Succinate dehydrogenase is a cytoplasmic enzyme that converts fumarate to succinate. It requires copper as a cofactor, and is inhibited by malonate.
Succinate dehydrogenase operates in the TCA cycle in the cytoplasm, does not require any metal ions, and is inhibited by oxaloacetate.
Succinate dehydrogenase is a mitochondrial enzyme involved in glucogenesis, does not require any metal cofactor, and is inhibited by acetyl-CoA.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about succinate dehydrogenase is correct?

choices.text: Stimulators: Glucagon and Cortisol; Inhibitors: Insulin and AMP
Stimulators: Insulin and AMP; Inhibitors: Glucagon and Cortisol
Stimulators: ATP and Insulin; Inhibitors: Glucagon and Acetyl-CoA
Stimulators: Glucagon and AMP; Inhibitors: Insulin and Fructose-2,6-bisphosphate

questions.text: Which of the following substances act as stimulators and inhibitors of gluconeogenesis?

choices.text: Glycogen is a branched polymer of glucose, with α-1,6-glycosidic bonds at the branch points and α-1,4-glycosidic bonds along the chains.
Glycogen is a linear polymer of glucose linked by β-1,4-glycosidic bonds, with no branching.
Glycogen is a branched polymer of fructose, with α-1,4-glycosidic bonds at the branch points and β-1,6-glycosidic bonds along the chains.
Glycogen is a branched polymer of glucose, with α-1,4-glycosidic bonds at the branch points and α-1,6-glycosidic bonds along the chains.

questions.text: Which of the following correctly describes the structure of glycogen?

choices.text: Glycogen Storage Disease Type I (Von Gierke's disease)
Glycogen Storage Disease Type III (Cori disease)

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with failure to thrive, hepatomegaly, and severe hypoglycemia after fasting for 8 hours. His lab results show lactic acidosis, hyperuricemia, and hyperlipidemia. The most likely diagnosis is:

choices.text: Enzyme replacement therapy (ERT) with recombinant human acid α-glucosidase initiated at this stage
Intravenous glucose supplementation to prevent hypoglycemia and maintain energy balance
High-dose corticosteroids to decrease inflammation and prevent muscle degeneration
Gene therapy using CRISPR/Cas9 technology to repair the GAA gene mu

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents with progressive muscle weakness, poor feeding, failure to thrive, and cardiomegaly. On examination, the infant has hepatomegaly, muscle hypotonia, and respiratory difficulty. Genetic testing reveals a mutated GAA gene leading to a deficiency in acid α-glucosidase. A muscle biopsy shows significant glycogen accumulation in lysosomes, and enzyme analysis confirms absent acid alpha-glucosidase activity. Which of the following is the most effective intervention to improve the long-term prognosis of this infant?

choices.text: Discontinue all sources of galactose from the diet, including breastfeeding, and initiate a galactose-free formula.
Administer glucose intravenously to correct hypoglycemia, followed by lifelong galactose supplementation.
Start high-dose vitamin K and monitor coagulation profiles regularly.
Begin enzyme replacement therapy (ERT) with recombinant galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase.

questions.text: A 3-day-old neonate with poor feeding, vomiting, hypoglycemia, and elevated galactose levels is diagnosed with Classical Galactosemia due to a GALT enzyme deficiency. What is the most appropriate initial treatment?

choices.text: Generation of NADPH to maintain the reduced form of glutathione, protecting cells from oxidative stress.
Synthesis of ATP for cellular energy in the absence of oxygen.
Production of ribose-5-phosphate for DNA and RNA synthesis in rapidly dividing cells.
Conversion of glucose to lactate as a byproduct of glycolysis to generate energy.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with hemolytic anemia and jaundice after a recent episode of infection. His lab results reveal elevated bilirubin, decreased hemoglobin, and decreased G6PD activity. The pentose phosphate pathway (HMP shunt) is important for protecting red blood cells from oxidative damage. Which of the following statements best describes a key function of the HMP shunt in red blood cells?

choices.text: Zebra bodies in lysosomes, indicative of gaucher disease
Cytoplasmic inclusions with zebra-pattern appearance in sphingolipid metabolism disorders
Tay-Sachs disease with cherry-red spot and lysosomal accumulation

questions.text: A histological slide shows a cell with zebra-like inclusion bodies, which appear as alternating dark and light stripes within the cytoplasm. This feature is characteristic of which of the following conditions?

choices.text: Fatty acids are activated to acyl-CoA in the cytoplasm, and the acyl-CoA is transported into the mitochondria via the carnitine shuttle, where it undergoes beta-oxidation. This process is inhibited by malonyl-CoA
Fatty acids are directly transported into the mitochondria in their unmodified form, where they undergo beta-oxidation, and carnitine is involved in activating fatty acids for oxidation
Fatty acids are first converted to acyl-CoA in the mitochondria, where they directly enter the beta-oxidation pathway without the need for a carnitine shuttle
The carnitine shuttle is responsible for transferring glucose derivatives into the mitochondria for glycolysis, with no involvement in fatty acid metabolism

questions.text: Which of the following accurately describes the regulation and the key steps involved in the transport of fatty acids into mitochondria for beta-oxidation?

A newborn presents with severe hypotonia, craniofacial dysmorphism, hepatic dysfunction, and high levels of very long-chain fatty acids in the blood. The biochemical defect responsible for this condition is associated with impaired function of which of the following organelles?

choices.text: Ketone bodies are produced in the liver from glucose and provide energy during fasting
Ketone bodies are produced in the liver from fatty acids and provide energy during fasting
Ketone bodies are produced in muscles and provide energy during exercise
Ketone bodies are only used by the liver for energy

questions.text: Which of the following is true about ketone bodies?
Which of the following is a primary bile acid?
A patient presents with premature atherosclerosis, xanthomas, and elevated serum cholesterol levels. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the LDL receptor gene. This condition is most likely to be:

A patient's lipid profile shows the following values:

1. HDL cholesterol = 45 mg/dL
2. LDL cholesterol = 120 mg/dL
3. Triglycerides = 200 mg/dL

Using the Friedewald formula for calculating total cholesterol (TC), which of the following is the correct value of total cholesterol?
1. HDL cholesterol = 45 mg/dL
2. LDL cholesterol = 120 mg/dL
3. Triglycerides = 200 mg/Dl

choices.text: DNA typically forms a right-handed helix, known as the B-form, which is the most common conformation in living cells
DNA typically forms a left-handed helix, which is the most common conformation in living cells
The right-handed helix of DNA is known as the A-form.
The left-handed helix of DNA is more stable and commonly found in nature.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the DNA structure is correct?

choices.text: Histone acetylation results in a more compact chromatin structure, repressing gene transcription
Histone acetylation adds acetyl groups to lysine residues on histones, leading to a more relaxed chromatin structure and activation of gene transcription
Histone acetylation involves the addition of methyl groups to histones, leading to gene activation
Histone acetylation prevents the binding of transcription factors to DNA, thus silencing gene expression

questions.text: Which of the following statements about histone acetylation is correct?
A 5-year-old male presents with severe motor dysfunction, self-injurious behavior, and gouty arthritis. This condition is most likely:
A 35-year-old patient presents with a family history of colon cancer and endometrial cancer at an early age. Genetic testing reveals a defect in mismatch repair genes. This condition is most likely:
Which of the following is the first purine nucleotide to be synthesized in the de novo purine biosynthesis pathway?

choices.text: Formation of the ribosome binding site (Shine-Dalgarno sequence)

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a typical post-transcriptional modification of eukaryotic mRNA?

choices.text: tRNA carries amino acids to the ribosome during translation, but does not have an anticodon loop.
The 3' end of tRNA is where the amino acid is attached, and it has a specific sequence for recognition by aminoacyl-tRNA synthetase.
tRNA serves as the template for protein synthesis and carries the information for the amino acid sequence.
tRNA is transcribed by RNA polymerase II in the nucleus and then undergoes translation directly in the cytoplasm.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about tRNA (Transfer RNA) is correct?

choices.text: A point mutation that causes the substitution of glutamic acid with valine at position 6 of the β-globin chain.
A point mutation that causes the substitution of lysine with aspartic acid at position 6 of the β-globin chain.
A frameshift mutation resulting in a truncated β-globin protein.
A duplication of the β-globin gene resulting in the production of an excess of β-globin chains.

questions.text: Sickle cell anemia is caused by a mutation in the β-globin gene. Which of the following best describes the mutation responsible for this condition?

choices.text: Cortical atrophy of the frontal lobe

questions.text: A 55-year-old alcoholic male presents with confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia. Which of the following findings would most likely be seen on imaging?
A 25-year-old vegan female presents with fatigue, pallor, and a sore tongue. Blood smear shows hypersegmented neutrophils. What is the next best step in management?
A 40-year-old vegetarian presents with alopecia, dermatitis, and conjunctivitis. He recently started consuming raw egg whites daily. Which of the following is the most likely deficiency?
A 35-year-old man presents with hyperpigmented, hyperkeratotic lesions on sun-exposed areas, diarrhea, and dementia. What is the most likely enzyme cofactor deficiency underlying his condition?
A child with mucopolysaccharidosis presents with dysostosis multiplex on X-ray. Which finding helps confirm the diagnosis of Hurler Syndrome over Hunter Syndrome?

A 6-month-old infant presents with irritability, diarrhea, and sharply demarcated erythematous and eczematous lesions around the mouth, hands, and feet. The lesions worsen with stress or illness. The child is exclusively breastfed, and the mother's zinc intake is adequate. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 4-year-old child presents with pallor, fatigue, and splenomegaly. Laboratory tests reveal hemolytic anemia with elevated reticulocyte count, bilirubin, and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH). The child's hemoglobin electrophoresis is normal. The most likely underlying defect is a deficiency in which of the following enzymes?

A baby is being evaluated for delayed developmental milestone. On examination, the child has hepatosplenomegaly. Microscopy of bone marrow/peripheral smear evaluation is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
Which of the following mineral deficiencies presents with alopecia dermatitis, loss of appetite and diminished healing?
Which of the following organelle has its own DNA?
Patient with reduced levels of HDL, ABCA1 mutation. What is the diagnosis?
Identify the graph?
Which of the following is the rate limiting enzyme of heme synthesis?
